title: Immediate Crisis Resources & Support
subtitle: If you or someone you know is in crisis, help is available 24/7
introduction:
If you or someone you know is in crisis, help is available 24/7

You are not alone. Crisis support is confidential, free, and always available. These resources are specifically designed to support healthcare professionals facing emotional distress, burnout, or crisis situations. Seeking help will not impact your professional standing or licensure.

quickAccessGuides.title: If You're Having Thoughts of Suicide

steps.description: Call 988 or text HOME to 741741 right now. Do not wait. Thoughts of suicide are treatable.
Contact a family member, close friend, colleague, or healthcare provider. Your life matters and people want to help.
Call 911 or go to your nearest emergency room. This is a medical emergency requiring immediate evaluation.
Work with a counselor to identify warning signs and coping strategies. Remove access to means of self-harm.

do: Talk about your feelings - silence makes depression worse
Keep taking medications as prescribed
Reach out to someone you trust
Stay in contact with mental health providers
Use crisis resources immediately if thoughts intensify
Give yourself time - recovery takes work but is absolutely possible
dont: Isolate yourself - isolation amplifies depression
Stop medications without talking to your doctor
Consume alcohol or use drugs to cope
Stay in triggering situations without support
Minimize how you're feeling or tough it out alone
Believe that this will always feel this way - it won't

quickAccessGuides.title: If You're Experiencing Severe Burnout or Crisis

steps.description: Burnout, moral injury, compassion fatigue, and occupational stress are real medical conditions affecting your health. Naming it is the first step.
Use For the Frontlines (text FRONTLINE to 741741) or your specialty's crisis resource (Physician Support Line, NNCC for nurses).
Most employers provide free, confidential counseling through Employee Assistance Programs. Check your benefits or ask HR.
Join a peer support group or contact a colleague who understands. Feeling understood is therapeutic.

do: Recognize burnout as a system problem, not a personal failure
Set boundaries between work and home time
Reach out to colleagues or peer support groups
Consider taking time off or reducing hours if possible
Address what's most draining (workload, ethics, staffing)
Practice self-compassion - you deserve care too
dont: Expect to fix this alone - burnout is a system issue
Ignore warning signs or push harder
Isolate from colleagues or friends
Make major life decisions while in acute burnout
Feel ashamed - burnout happens to the best clinicians
Wait for things to improve on their own

quickAccessGuides.title: If You're Experiencing Moral Injury or Ethical Distress

steps.description: Moral injury occurs when you witness or are forced to participate in actions that violate your core values. This creates profound distress, shame, and guilt.

steps.action: Reach out to someone who understands
steps.description: Moral injury is unique to healthcare. Seek providers trained in trauma and moral injury, or peer groups that specifically address healthcare ethics.
If systemic issues caused the moral injury, connect with your institution's ethics committee or medical board advocacy. Your voice matters.
Cognitive therapy and trauma-focused approaches specifically help with moral injury. Therapists trained in healthcare provider trauma can help.

do: Name the specific values that were violated
Talk about the experience with someone who gets healthcare ethics
Consider therapy specifically designed for moral injury
Work toward internal forgiveness - you did your best in a broken system
Channel your distress into advocacy for change
Remember: the system failed you, not the reverse
dont: Internalize that you did something wrong when systems failed
Try to suppress or minimize the distress
Work with a therapist who doesn't understand healthcare context
Stay silent about systemic problems causing moral injury
Believe you're weak or inadequate for being affected
Isolate or blame yourself entirely

quickAccessGuides.title: If You're Using Substances to Cope

steps.description: Call SAMHSA National Helpline (1-800-662-4357) or your state Physician Health Program. This is not a moral failing - it's a medical condition.
A trained professional can assess your substance use and recommend treatment. Many options are available and evidence-based.
Treatment options range from outpatient counseling to inpatient programs. Your EAP or insurance can help coordinate care.
Peer support in recovery is crucial. AA, NA, SMART Recovery, and healthcare-specific groups offer community and accountability.

do: Reach out - substance use issues are medical, treatable conditions
Be honest about your use with healthcare providers
Access confidential state programs (PHPs) designed to protect your license
Build accountability with peers in recovery
Address underlying trauma or burnout driving the use
Develop new coping strategies with professional support
dont: Try to manage this alone - recovery needs support
Delay seeking help hoping it goes away
Minimize your use or hide it from providers
Self-report to your medical board without legal/program guidance first
Give up on recovery - long-term remission is possible
Lose hope - many healthcare providers are in recovery

quickAccessGuides.title: If You're Concerned About a Colleague in Crisis

steps.description: If a colleague mentions suicidal thoughts, substance use, or severe distress, take it at face value. Don't assume they're just venting.
Ask 'Are you thinking of harming yourself?' directly. Research shows asking doesn't increase risk - it can save lives. Listen without judgment.
Suggest specific resources (988, Physician Support Line, For the Frontlines) or offer to help them call. Don't try to be their therapist.
If they're in immediate danger, call 911. If safety isn't imminent, help connect them to professional support.

do: Take mental health concerns seriously
Ask directly about suicidal thoughts if you're concerned
Listen compassionately without trying to fix it
Help them access professional resources
Follow up after the crisis - recovery takes time
Take care of your own mental health too
dont: Ignore warning signs thinking it will pass
Assume they'll reach out if it's serious
Try to be their therapist or counselor
Share their crisis information without permission
Minimize their feelings or tell them to 'toughen up'
Take responsibility for their recovery - that's their job with professionals

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Physicians
key_challenges: Moral injury from systemic healthcare failures
Burnout from EHR burden and administrative tasks
Imposter syndrome and high stakes decision-making
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Physicians often face unique barriers: fear of licensure consequences, perfectionism, and professional identity deeply intertwined with self-worth. The Physician Support Line is staffed by psychiatrists who understand these pressures. State PHPs are completely separate from licensing boards and provide confidential support. Know that 37 state medical boards and 600+ hospitals now have best-practice standards protecting physicians seeking mental health care.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Nurses
key_challenges: Severe burnout from understaffing and high patient ratios
Physical exhaustion and shift-related health issues
Moral injury from witnessing patient suffering
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Nurses uniquely experience burnout from systemic understaffing and moral distress. The National Nurses Crisis Center provides 24/7 AI-powered support designed for nurses' specific challenges. For the Frontlines is specifically for healthcare workers. Many nurses hesitate to seek help due to stigma; remember that seeking support is an act of strength and self-care, not weakness.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Pharmacists
key_challenges: Medication safety responsibility and fear of errors
Burnout from high volume and understaffing
Limited recognition of medication therapy expertise
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Pharmacists often work in isolated settings with high stakes around medication safety. Crisis resources including the 988 Lifeline, For the Frontlines, and EAPs are available. If your workplace offers Mental Health First Aid training (now available at reduced cost through many pharmacy associations), consider participating to build confidence in seeking help when needed.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Therapists & Counselors
key_challenges: Moral injury from witnessing client suffering
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Therapists and counselors experience unique trauma from supporting clients through crises. Your vicarious trauma is real and treatable. Seek supervision, consultation, and personal therapy with providers who understand therapist burnout. Don't Clock Out and Emotional PPE Project specifically support mental health professionals. Regular self-care and professional boundaries are essential prevention.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Medical Residents & Trainees
key_challenges: High stress during formative training years
Work hour restrictions impact education and fatigue
Sleep deprivation and its mental health impact
Fear of reporting concerns due to evaluations
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Trainees face particular challenges: financial stress, hierarchical power dynamics, and fear that seeking help will impact evaluations. Know that your training program should have confidential mental health resources. The Physician Support Line welcomes medical students and residents. Many programs now have resident wellness consultants and peer support. Your program director and GME office can connect you with confidential resources.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Medical Assistants
key_challenges: High patient contact volume with limited recognition
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: Medical assistants are often frontline healthcare workers experiencing high emotional and physical demands. 988 and For the Frontlines are designed for frontline workers. Many medical assisting roles include EAP benefits - ask your employer's HR department. You deserve mental health support and care, just as your patients do. Your well-being matters.

supportedProviderGuides.title: Crisis Resources for Nurse Practitioners
key_challenges: Dual identity - nurse training plus provider role
supportedProviderGuides.specific_guidance: NPs experience challenges from both nursing and medical perspectives. Many state medical boards now welcome NPs into state health programs (check your state PHP). For the Frontlines and the National Nurses Crisis Center both support NPs. Seek peer mentorship from NPs who have navigated similar challenges. Your unique training and perspective are valuable assets.

signs: Active thoughts of suicide or self-harm
Detailed suicide plan or access to means
Expressing that others would be better off without you
Saying goodbye or putting affairs in order
Sudden mood changes from severe depression to unusual calm
Dangerous substance use or overdose risk
Severe panic or feeling completely out of control
Suicidal statements: 'I can't take this anymore' or 'I want to die'
critical.immediate_action: Call 911 or 988 now. Go to nearest emergency room. Tell someone immediately.

signs: Persistent thoughts of suicide (even without a plan)
Severe depression or hopelessness lasting days/weeks
Inability to work or perform basic self-care
Increased substance use or reckless behavior
Feeling trapped with no way out
Complete social withdrawal and isolation
Giving away possessions or making major decisions suddenly
Expressing feeling like a burden to others
high.immediate_action: Contact 988, your EAP, Physician Support Line, or go to urgent care/ED today.

signs: Persistent sadness, anxiety, or irritability
Sleep changes (too much or too little)
Difficulty concentrating or making decisions
Loss of interest in activities you usually enjoy
Increased substance use to cope
Feeling overwhelmed at work
Relationship stress or conflict
Physical symptoms (headaches, fatigue, pain)
moderate.immediate_action: Contact your EAP, schedule with your therapist/doctor, or join a support group.

detailedGuide:
Understanding Healthcare Provider Mental Health Crises

Different Types of Crisis

Healthcare providers experience various types of mental health crises, each requiring specific support:

  • Acute Suicidal Crisis: Immediate thoughts of self-harm requiring emergency intervention (988, 911, ED)
  • Burnout Crisis: Cumulative exhaustion from workload, moral distress, and systemic failures
  • Moral Injury: Profound distress from witnessing or participating in actions violating core values
  • Trauma Response: Acute or cumulative trauma from patient suffering, mass casualty events, or occupational exposure
  • Substance Use Crisis: Escalating substance use as a coping mechanism (highly treatable through PHPs)
Why Healthcare-Specific Resources Matter

Healthcare professionals face unique stressors that general crisis lines may not fully understand:

Challenge Why It Matters Specialized Response
Moral injury and ethical distress Deep psychological impact when forced to violate values Therapists trained in healthcare ethics and trauma-informed care
Professional identity and licensure concerns Fear that seeking help threatens career and license State PHPs, peer support from providers, confidentiality assurances
Compassion fatigue and burnout Systemic healthcare stressors create cumulative exhaustion Resources recognizing system-level problems, advocacy support
Perfectionism and stigma Provider culture discourages vulnerability and help-seeking Peer support from those in healthcare, normalizing mental health care
When to Reach Out for Help

Do not wait. Reach out when:

  • You're thinking about harming yourself - call 988 immediately
  • You feel hopeless or trapped for more than a few days
  • You're using substances to cope with stress
  • You can't perform your job or daily activities
  • You feel you're a burden to others
  • You're withdrawing from relationships and activities
  • Work-related ethical situations are causing severe distress
  • You recognize signs of crisis in a colleague
Confidentiality & Legal Protections

This is critical: Seeking mental health care will not automatically impact your license or career.

  • State Physician Health Programs (PHPs): Completely separate from medical boards. PHPs maintain confidentiality and provide recovery support.
  • 988 Lifeline: Not reported to employers, licensing boards, or law enforcement. Completely anonymous if you wish.
  • EAP Services: Separate from employer HR and medical records. Confidential by federal law.
  • State Best Practices: 37 state medical boards and 600+ hospitals have removed stigmatizing questions about past mental health treatment on licensing/credentialing applications.
  • Know Your State: Rules vary by state. Organizations like the Dr. Lorna Breen Foundation provide state-specific guidance.
How to Help a Colleague in Crisis

If you're concerned about a colleague:

  1. Take it seriously. Don't minimize or assume they're just venting.
  2. Ask directly. Research shows asking about suicide doesn't increase risk—it can save lives. 'Are you thinking about harming yourself?'
  3. Listen without judgment. Let them express their feelings. Don't try to fix it or minimize their experience.
  4. Share specific resources. Don't just say 'get help.' Provide specific numbers or websites.
  5. Help them reach out. Offer to call with them or sit with them while they text 988.
  6. Know when to escalate. If they're in immediate danger, call 911. If not, help connect to professional resources.
  7. Follow up. Recovery takes time. Check in after the crisis has passed.
  8. Take care of yourself. Supporting a colleague in crisis can affect your own mental health. Access support for yourself too.
After the Crisis: Recovery & Next Steps

Surviving a mental health crisis is the beginning, not the end. Recovery requires ongoing support:

  • Connect with ongoing therapy: Individual therapy helps process what happened and develop long-term coping strategies.
  • Join peer support groups: Ongoing peer support from people who understand healthcare provider challenges is therapeutic and sustaining.
  • Address underlying issues: Burnout, moral injury, and trauma require more than crisis intervention. Address root causes with professional help.
  • Consider your work environment: If your workplace contributed to the crisis, consider changes: negotiating workload, seeking a different role, or transitioning to a healthier setting.
  • Build resilience: Develop sustainable practices: exercise, sleep, relationships, boundaries, spirituality, hobbies, mentorship.
  • Stay connected to Fulcrum resources: Use Fulcrum's provider wellness content to support ongoing mental health alongside crisis resources.
Recovery is Possible

Your struggle does not define you. Many healthcare providers have faced crisis and recovered to live meaningful, fulfilling lives. Statistics show:

  • State Physician Health Programs have recovery rates exceeding general population, with successful outcomes even 5+ years into monitoring
  • Substance use disorder is highly treatable—recovery rates improve significantly with structured support
  • Therapy and peer support are effective for moral injury, burnout, and occupational trauma
  • Thousands of healthcare providers are actively in recovery and thriving in their careers and personal lives

Your life has value. Your health matters. Help is available. Recovery is possible.

Crisis Text Line

resources.html:
For the Frontlines

National Nurses Crisis Center
